title: Portfolio — Leonardo Benvinda
about_text: I have been passionate about technology for as long as I can remember. My interests are as varied as software development, IoT, Artificial Intelligence, systems administration, hardware repair and maintenance, among other areas. I enjoy practical challenges, but I also highly value the theory and planning behind a good project. I believe that technology should be used to improve people's lives, and I am always looking for new ways to learn and grow in this ever-evolving field. The different types of projects I have developed over the years reflect my curiosity for various areas. I recently completed my bachelor's degree in Computer Engineering, where I acquired and deepened knowledge in several areas, and I am now looking for my first professional experience in the field.
edu_1_institution: School of Technology and Management - Polytechnic Institute of Beja
edu_1_desc: Highly practical course with an emphasis on object-oriented programming (OOP), web development, and scripting. Final project: Development of a mobile video surveillance solution with real-time streaming and remote control via a web application - Grade: 20/20. Final Average: 16/20.
edu_2_desc: Main focus on object-oriented programming and databases. Final Project: Management software for a medical clinic - Grade: 19/20. Final Average: 16/20.
pos_1_desc: Development of internal management applications. Installation, maintenance, and repair of hardware and software on school computers and networks. Technical support for students and teachers. Preparation, configuration, and deployment of systems.
pos_2_title: Founding Member and Secretary of Cultural Association
pos_2_desc: Founding member and secretary of a local non-profit cultural association focused on promoting artistic and cultural events in the parish of Alvalade do Sado. Web development of the event website Alvalade Arise (www.alvaladearise.com).
project_1_desc: Web platform for student accommodation listings.
project_1_details: SGAE was designed to centralize and simplify the search for accommodation by students of the Polytechnic Institute of Beja.
project_1_details_2: Some of the main features include: user authentication for two types (owners and students), creation and management of accommodation listings, search system with advanced filters (location, price, type of accommodation), administration panel for content moderation and user management, and a responsive design for mobile device access. Another implemented feature was the ability to enable and disable ad moderation, allowing greater control over the content published on the platform.
project_1_details_3: The platform was developed using Laravel MVC, providing a robust and scalable structure. The database modeling was optimized to support future expansions and was implemented with MySQL. For the administration panel, the Fillament package was used. For authentication, Laravel Fortify was used, and Spatie was used for user permissions and roles management. The frontend was developed with Bootstrap, also using the SASS tool.
project_1_details_4: This project was a collaborative effort, developed by me and another colleague over a semester, as part of the Integrated Project course in the 2023/2024 academic year.
project_2_desc: Web platform for rating craft beers.
project_2_details: The goal of this project was to create a web platform for rating craft beers, where producers can showcase their products and enthusiasts can discover new beers, rate them, and contribute to a community focused on sharing experiences. This is a project I was very excited to work on. Besides considering it to be very well-executed, I find it an interesting proposal that, as a craft beer enthusiast, I would find very useful for cataloging the different beers I have tried.
project_2_details_2: The platform consists of a REST API, developed in the Web Application Development course. This API, developed in PHP with the Laravel framework, complemented by a MySQL database, provided the necessary structure to implement: secure registration and authentication, with the help of the Laravel Fortify package; Submission of new beers by producers; Search for beers and brands through various filters; Beer rating by registered users; and Permissions and roles management, integrated with the Spatie package.
project_2_details_3: For the front-end, developed in the Web Technologies and Mobile Environments course, I used React.js to create a clean, accessible, and responsive interface for the project's front end.
project_3_desc: Android launcher focused on accessibility for the elderly and people with similar accessibility needs.
project_3_details: This project had as one of its main focuses to make smartphones more accessible for elderly people, facilitating the integration of this population group into the digital world. This Android launcher, developed in Kotlin, offers a simplified interface with large, easy-to-identify icons, quick access to essential phone functions such as calls, messages, and camera, and the inclusion of an SOS function that allows users to quickly send an emergency message with their location to predefined contacts.
project_3_details_2: If all projects should consider user experience, in this case, this aspect was entirely central to how the launcher was designed and developed.
project_3_details_3: This project was developed in a team, including two other colleagues, as part of the Mobile Device Programming course in the 2024/2025 academic year.
project_4_desc: Gas detection system with IoT integration for remote monitoring.
project_4_details: GASPAR is a gas detection system developed with the goal of proving a concept rather than being a complex project. The aim was to try to create something useful using as many plug-and-play resources as possible, showing that it is possible to create practical solutions with a limited budget and accessible components.
project_4_details_2: The core of the system is an Arduino UNO R4 Wifi, equipped with an MQ-2 gas sensor that, upon detecting potentially dangerous gas levels, sends notifications to a smartphone via the IFTTT (If This Then That (https://ifttt.com/)) service to alert users. The system also integrates an on-site alarm to immediately warn people nearby. For continuous monitoring, sensor data is sent to the Arduino Cloud, where it can be viewed in real-time through a dedicated dashboard.
project_4_details_3: This project was developed as part of the Applied Physics to Computing course in the 2023/2024 academic year.
project_5_desc: A version of the classic Sokoban game developed in Java, with a JavaFX graphical interface.
project_5_details: The focus of this project was to develop clean and well-organized code, using the MVC (Model-View-Controller) design pattern to separate the game logic, user interface, and game flow control. The game includes features such as multiple levels, a scoring system, undo and redo functions for player moves, and the ability to save and load game progress, replaying the steps taken by the player. The graphical interface was developed using JavaFX, providing a pleasant and interactive visual experience for players.
project_5_details_2: During development, I used more advanced Java concepts, such as records, enums, interfaces, inheritance, and polymorphism, to ensure the code was efficient and easy to maintain.
project_5_details_3: With an emphasis on code quality, tests were also created for the main functionalities of the game, ensuring its robustness and reliability.
project_5_details_4: This was a collaborative project, developed with a colleague, as part of the Object-Oriented Programming course in the 2022/2023 academic year.
project_6_title: Football Match Outcome Prediction with Machine Learning
project_6_desc: Training Machine Learning models to predict football match outcomes using only statistical data.
project_6_details: This project explores the application of machine learning algorithms to predict football match outcomes (home win, draw, or away win), using the Orange software and a dataset extracted from Kaggle, based on Transfermarkt. Several models were trained, including Logistic Regression, Decision Tree, Neural Network, Random Forest, kNN (K-Nearest Neighbors), and Gradient Boosting.
project_6_details_2: One of the main objectives of this project was to evaluate the performance of these models using only statistical data, without relying on contextual or subjective information, as is the case with betting companies, which include human prediction factors in their calculations. As predictive variables, the last 5 previous results of the teams were considered, both against each other and individually. Training data from 2013 to 2021 was used, testing was done with data from 2022 and 2023, and predictions were made using data from 2024.
project_6_details_3: The mentioned models were evaluated based on Accuracy, Precision, Recall, and F1-Score metrics. The model that achieved the best performance was Gradient Boosting, obtaining the best values for all the mentioned indicators. The confusion matrix also reveals a considerable accuracy of 54.8% in predicting draws, which are traditionally harder to predict due to their unpredictable nature.
project_6_details_4: For data cleaning and preparation, I used Python, while the machine learning models were trained and evaluated using the Orange software.
project_6_details_5: In addition to training and evaluating the models, I wrote a detailed article that not only describes the development process but also provides a deeper analysis of the results obtained and their implications in the context of sports outcome prediction. This article can be accessed through the link below.
project_6_details_6: This project was developed as part of the Information Systems course during the 2024/2025 academic year.
project_7_desc: Data processing software for submitting the Unique Report to Social Security.
project_7_details: While working at ETLA, I developed a desktop application in C# to automate the data processing required for submitting Annex C of the Unique Report to Social Security (https://help.factorialhr.com/pt_PT/formacao/como-preencher-o-anexo-c-do-relatorio-unico). A process that was previously done through multiple and complex Excel spreadsheets is now simplified with this application.
project_7_details_2: This application was one of the most challenging in terms of integration with other systems. The data was extracted from various management systems into Excel sheets, so its format and structure were not consistent. ARU was developed with this particularity in mind, and it includes a 'header' reading functionality to attempt to automatically map the input data to the format expected by the application. When the headers are not recognized, the user can manually map the fields, ensuring the necessary flexibility to handle different data sources.
project_7_details_3: Considering human error as an inevitable factor, the application also includes a duplicate record detection system, alerting the user to possible inconsistencies in the data before generating the final file. After processing and validating the data, the application generates a file in XML format, ready for submission to Social Security, significantly simplifying the process and reducing the risk of errors.
project_7_details_4: A functionality was also implemented to automatically fill in some form data based on historical data, further reducing the time required to complete the report. This functionality was implemented using a version of the Levenshtein algorithm to compare the names of training sessions given to employees, identifying their topics within those available in the official Social Security table.
project_7_details_5: For confidentiality reasons, I cannot share screenshots or specific details of the source code for this project.
project_8_desc: Simple inventory software for microbusinesses without formal bookkeeping.
project_8_details: Balançómetro is an inventory software tool I developed to address a need in a family business that did not have formal bookkeeping. Every year, to submit the balance sheet to the Tax Authority, it was necessary to manually inventory all products in stock, which was time-consuming and prone to errors.
project_8_details_2: An initial solution was simply to create an Excel spreadsheet to make the process easier, but product searches were still slow and imprecise. Better mechanisms for searching and updating the data were needed.
project_8_details_3: I then built the first version of Balançómetro in C#, with a simple graphical interface that allowed importing the product list exported by the POS system in .xlsx format. The user could then enter current stock quantities, update prices, and generate another Excel sheet ready to be handed over to accounting. The main advantage of this software over a spreadsheet was primarily its search functions, allowing the combination of filters such as price, description, and product code. It may be seen as a simple project, but it still had a major impact on the efficiency of this microbusiness’s annual inventory process.
project_8_details_4: However, over time, as the number and diversity of products grew, it became clear the software needed improvements to handle these new requirements. So I developed a second version of Balançómetro, incorporating additional features to improve usability and inventory efficiency. This new version uses a more modern stack—Rust, Tauri, and Svelte—to create a lightweight and efficient desktop application and, above all, a cross-platform one, enabling its use on different operating systems. This also sets the stage for the program’s next evolution to be integrated into mobile devices, making the inventory process even easier.
project_8_details_5: The new features focus mainly on improving the search system by implementing advanced description searches, using techniques such as the Levenshtein algorithm and fuzzy search to find products with similar descriptions, even if they are not exactly the same. This is particularly important for dealing with typos or variations in product naming. There is also search by code and price, both exact and by price ranges. In addition, a feature was implemented that allows mathematical operations to be performed directly in the quantity field, avoiding the need to manually calculate quantities and then replace the value. For example, if a product has 10 units in stock and the user wants to add 5 more, they can simply type "+5" in the quantity field, and the software will automatically update the value to 15. This significantly simplifies the stock update process, making it faster and less error-prone.
project_8_details_6: This project, despite being simple in essence, had a significant impact on the efficiency of this microbusiness’s annual inventory process, showing how technology solutions tailored to specific needs can bring tangible benefits even in small and informal business contexts. It is also a testament to my evolution as a software creator, with clear progression from a traditional C# desktop application to a modern, cross-platform solution using Rust, Tauri, and Svelte. The second version also shows a stronger focus on user experience, implementing features that make it easier to use and improve the efficiency of the inventory process.
project_9_desc: Software for mapping a QWERTY keyboard to send MIDI commands.
project_9_details: This is a project born out of a personal need. As an amateur musician, I have been using sound modeling software for some time to avoid purchasing expensive hardware. Much of this software can be controlled via MIDI commands, usually issued by keyboards or other MIDI devices.
project_9_details_2: That said, I always thought that using a specific keyboard just to control software running on a common computer was somewhat redundant. Couldn't I simply use a regular keyboard to send these MIDI commands? After some research, I didn't find many viable solutions, so I decided to develop my own software for this purpose. VMK is software developed in C# that allows me to map keys on a regular keyboard, define specific MIDI commands for each key, and thus control sound modeling software without the need for additional hardware.
project_9_details_3: It is a personal project that is still in a very early stage, butin recent tests, it has already allowed sending basic MIDI commands. It does not yet have a visual interface or the ability to map keys, so both the commands and the mapped keys are still hardcoded. However, it is a project I intend to continue developing in my free time and, who knows, one day turn it into a useful tool for other amateur musicians like me.
project_10_desc: A blog that automatically generates articles using AI.
project_10_details: In a efford to explore the DevOps field and it's technologies, i´ve challanged myself to create a project that could apply technologies like Docker and AWS services. Someone suggested me that for this purpose, an auto-written blog using AI could be an interesting idea. So, I created a blog that automatically generates articles using AI, using HuggingFace API.
project_10_details_2: For those who are not familiar with the term, the 'Dead Internet Theory' is a conspiracy theory that suggests that a significant portion of the internet is now generated by artificial intelligence rather than humans. So, a AI-written blog about this topic seemed like an ironic and fitting choice... or at least that's what THEY want us to believe!!!
project_10_details_3: Back to the technical side, the blog is hosted on AWS using an EC2 instance, with Docker containers managing the application and its dependencies. The articles are generated using HuggingFace's language models, which provide high-quality text generation capabilities. The blog is designed to periodically generate new articles on the topic, keeping the content fresh and engaging for visitors.
project_10_details_4: This project also included setting up deployment pipelines that garanted a smooth and automated update process whenever changes were made to the Github codebase. This way, whenever I push updates to the code repository, the changes are automatically deployed to the AWS instance, ensuring that the blog is always running the latest version.
project_10_details_5: Apart from the auto-generated periodic posts, the app also allows visitors to suggest a topic for a conspiracy theory article, that will be promptly written and posted in the website. This project was a great opportunity to learn and apply DevOps practices, as well as to explore the capabilities of AI in content generation.
project_10_details_6: You can check the blog out at: http://13.51.161.44/
